verses.text: Now the Spirit of God came upon Azariah the son of Oded.
verses.comment: Azariah is introduced as a prophet empowered by God's Spirit.

verses.text: He went out to meet Asa and said to him, 'Hear me, Asa, and all Judah and Benjamin! The LORD is with you while you are with Him. If you seek Him, He will be found by you, but if you forsake Him, He will forsake you.'
verses.comment: Clear conditional promise: God's presence depends on Israel's loyalty.

verses.text: For a long time Israel was without the true God, without a teaching priest, and without law.
verses.comment: Describes spiritual neglect in Israel's history.

verses.text: But when they turned in their trouble to the LORD, the God of Israel, and sought Him, He was found by them.
verses.comment: Echoes God's promise to respond to true repentance.

verses.text: In those days there was no peace for those who went out or came in, for great unrest fell upon all the inhabitants of the lands.
verses.comment: References a time of instability affecting all people.

verses.text: Nation was crushed by nation, and city by city, for God troubled them with every kind of adversity.
verses.comment: God causes the distress due to their unfaithfulness.

verses.text: But you, be strong and do not let your hands be weak, for your work will be rewarded.'

When Asa heard these words and the prophecy of Azariah the son of Oded the prophet, he took courage and removed the disgusting idols from all the land of Judah and Benjamin and from the cities he had captured in the hill country of Ephraim, and he repaired the altar of the LORD that was in front of the vestibule of the LORD’s temple.
verses.comment: Idols described as 'disgusting' for emphasis; Asa restores proper worship.

verses.text: He gathered all Judah and Benjamin, and those from Ephraim, Manasseh, and Simeon who had resided with them, for many had come over to him from Israel when they saw that the LORD his God was with him.
verses.comment: People from the northern tribes joined Asa due to God's blessing.

verses.text: They assembled in Jerusalem in the third month of the fifteenth year of Asa's reign.
On that day they offered to the LORD seven hundred oxen and seven thousand sheep from the spoil they had brought.
verses.comment: Sacrifices offered as acts of worship with the spoils of victory.

verses.text: They entered into a covenant to seek the LORD, the God of their fathers, with all their heart and with all their soul,
verses.comment: The people's commitment echoes Mosaic and Davidic devotion.

verses.text: and whoever would not seek the LORD, the God of Israel, was to be put to death, whether young or old, man or woman.
verses.comment: Reflects Mosaic law’s severe consequences for apostasy.

verses.text: They took an oath to the LORD with a loud voice, with shouting, trumpets, and horns.
verses.comment: Public affirmation of the covenant accompanied by music and shouting.

verses.text: All Judah rejoiced over the oath, for they had sworn with all their heart and had sought Him wholeheartedly, and He was found by them, and the LORD gave them rest on every side.
verses.comment: God’s reward for sincere devotion: rest and peace.

verses.text: Even Maacah, the mother of King Asa, he removed from being queen mother because she had made an obscene image for Asherah. Asa cut down her obscene image, ground it to dust, and burned it at the brook Kidron.
verses.comment: Asherah image called ‘obscene’ for clarity; same word as used for idols in v.8.

verses.text: But the high places were not taken away from Israel. Nevertheless, Asa’s heart was wholly true all his days.
verses.comment: Asa’s incomplete reforms contrasted with his consistent loyalty to God.

verses.text: He brought into the house of God the dedicated things of his father and his own dedicated things, silver, gold, and vessels.
And there was no more war until the thirty-fifth year of Asa’s reign.
verses.comment: Indicates a long period of peace as God’s blessing for reform.
